title: Introduction to JavaScript
subject: JavaScript
learning_objectives: Learn the history and role of JavaScript in web development
Understand the difference between Client-side and Server-side scripting
theory:
JavaScript is a lightweight, interpreted, or just-in-time compiled programming language with first-class functions. While it is most well-known as the scripting language for Web pages, many non-browser environments also use it, such as Node.js, Apache CouchDB and Adobe Acrobat.

JavaScript is the programming language of the Web. Along with HTML and CSS, it is one of the three core technologies of the World Wide Web.
syntax:
// JavaScript code can be placed in <script> tags or external files
console.log("Hello World");

examples.code: My First JavaScript
examples.output: A button that, when clicked, displays the current date and time in the paragraph below it.
examples.explanation: This demonstrates JavaScript's ability to manipulate HTML content dynamically.

common_mistakes.correction: Java and JavaScript are completely different languages with different purposes. Java is a general-purpose language, while JavaScript was originally designed for the web.

interview_questions.question: Who developed JavaScript?
interview_questions.answer: Brendan Eich created JavaScript in 1995 while working at Netscape.

interview_questions.question: Is JavaScript a compiled or interpreted language?
interview_questions.answer: Historically interpreted, modern JS engines (like V8) use Just-in-Time (JIT) compilation to improve performance.

practice_problems.problem: Write a JavaScript statement to print 'Hello' to the console.

real_world_use_cases.description: Validating user input before sending it to a server.

exam_notes: JavaScript was originally named Mocha, then LiveScript.
ECMAScript is the official standard specification for JavaScript.
summary: JavaScript brings web pages to life. It is the only language that runs natively in every web browser.
